headline: Public Storage, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's Ross Nussbaum here with Christy. I'm thinking about the topic of move-ins versus move-outs, because the industry data we've seen, and I think some of the results from your peers have suggested that occupancy gains have been more a function of lower m
componenttext: It's Ross Nussbaum here with Christy. I'm thinking about the topic of move-ins versus move-outs, because the industry data we've seen, and I think some of the results from your peers have suggested that occupancy gains have been more a function of lower move-outs rather than more move-ins. Is that consistent with what you're seeing as well?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ross, if I -- I mentioned that we had about 20,000 net customers for the quarter. We had 4% higher move-ins or about 8,000, 8,500. But we had about 6% higher move-outs or 11,000 versus last year.
componenttext: Ross, if I -- I mentioned that we had about 20,000 net customers for the quarter. We had 4% higher move-ins or about 8,000, 8,500. But we had about 6% higher move-outs or 11,000 versus last year.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: You actually sort of benefited from a little of both?
componenttext: You actually sort of benefited from a little of both?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. It was on both sides of the table, but our move-outs were slightly higher than the move-in.
componenttext: Yes. It was on both sides of the table, but our move-outs were slightly higher than the move-in.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. How aggressively do you think you can run up street rents now that you're back to basically -- I think the highest occupancy I've seen out of you in the last decade is maybe in the 92% somewhere. So you're getting close to that. At what point do yo
componenttext: Okay. How aggressively do you think you can run up street rents now that you're back to basically -- I think the highest occupancy I've seen out of you in the last decade is maybe in the 92% somewhere. So you're getting close to that. At what point do you turn on the street rent spigot such that you're pumping out 3%, 4%, 5% rent growth on that front?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ross, it's kind of tough to do that unless you're well below competition. If we start pushing it up well above competition just to drive rates up, because we're highly occupied, I can guarantee you what will happen, our move-in volume will shrink. So we j
componenttext: Ross, it's kind of tough to do that unless you're well below competition. If we start pushing it up well above competition just to drive rates up, because we're highly occupied, I can guarantee you what will happen, our move-in volume will shrink. So we just don't drive them out just because we're full. We also need to be cognizant that we're in a highly competitive industry and we have a lot of competitors out there that are doing a lot of pricing and promotion, as well as we are. And so we're very cognizant about that as we move street rates and don't want to get too out of whack. Last year, I've mentioned that I felt like we got our street rates too high and I think we gave away some market share as we did that. This year, I can guarantee we won't be doing that.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Harris with Gleacher & Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Harris with Gleacher & Company.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: You know how schizoid we folks are in the capital markets. And it seems like the spook this week is about the economy slowing down in the second half. Are you seeing anything that into your real-time reports from the [indiscernible], Ron?
componenttext: You know how schizoid we folks are in the capital markets. And it seems like the spook this week is about the economy slowing down in the second half. Are you seeing anything that into your real-time reports from the [indiscernible], Ron?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, David. I mean, we're heading into May, as I mentioned at about 91.3%. That's where we were in June of last year. So we're about a month, 1.5 months ahead in terms of hitting our peak occupancy this year. Demand is robust across the platform. And as Jo
componenttext: No, David. I mean, we're heading into May, as I mentioned at about 91.3%. That's where we were in June of last year. So we're about a month, 1.5 months ahead in terms of hitting our peak occupancy this year. Demand is robust across the platform. And as John mentioned, he's modulating the promotional discounts and we're dialing back the media spend. So I'd take away from that from what we're seeing, we're fairly confident about our ability to kind of hold pricing and hold volumes. It's a real time thing, it changes week to week. But what we're seeing to date is that it's pretty decent demand across the platform.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: I mean, when we see move in the economy, I mean, the spike in oil prices led to much greater energy price inflation, for example, or substantial job losses. I mean, how quickly does that typically translate through to the tenant demand that you see? Does
componenttext: I mean, when we see move in the economy, I mean, the spike in oil prices led to much greater energy price inflation, for example, or substantial job losses. I mean, how quickly does that typically translate through to the tenant demand that you see? Does it take a while? Or is it pretty simultaneous?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that the big picture, and I really can't answer that question in detail, but the big picture is from 2 years ago, people are out of their bunkers, they're out doing things. Unemployment, yes, is still at 9%, but people are out doing things.
componenttext: Well, I think that the big picture, and I really can't answer that question in detail, but the big picture is from 2 years ago, people are out of their bunkers, they're out doing things. Unemployment, yes, is still at 9%, but people are out doing things. There's more activity today than there was 2 years ago. And all of that is very good for our business.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to go back to your earlier comments when you thought that development might pick up more next year, which I think is a little bit different from maybe what we've talked about a couple of quarters ago, where just given the asset class and ban
componenttext: I just wanted to go back to your earlier comments when you thought that development might pick up more next year, which I think is a little bit different from maybe what we've talked about a couple of quarters ago, where just given the asset class and banks' unwillingness to lend to shorter-term assets that don't prelease, et cetera. Are you seeing that change in the field? Or you were thinking more the larger private operators or public companies might get back in development? I mean, I know that you said you wouldn't, but just maybe a little more detail on what you're seeing there or thinking there?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't know what the other public companies are doing or thinking of. I just look at the pricing of some of the assets that are trading and what that is relative to replacement costs, and go sometime down the road and a developer type will show up there
componenttext: I don't know what the other public companies are doing or thinking of. I just look at the pricing of some of the assets that are trading and what that is relative to replacement costs, and go sometime down the road and a developer type will show up there and start to put some product up. And my guess, it will be, as usual, Texas will be the first place.

componenttext: And so we're talking $44 million to $50 million for the year. The 10-K had $35 million to $40 million. And so what was the big change in projection relative to, I guess, what was put out in early March?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: The big change has to do, Michael, with the stock-based compensation expense that I've mentioned in my prepared remarks. That will be averaging $2.3 million for the quarter, for each quarter. It was $2.3 million in the first quarter. It will be $2.3 mi
componenttext: The big change has to do, Michael, with the stock-based compensation expense that I've mentioned in my prepared remarks. That will be averaging $2.3 million for the quarter, for each quarter. It was $2.3 million in the first quarter. It will be $2.3 million in each quarter going forward for a total of about $9 million. That was not estimated -- because that program was not in place at the time we disclosed the numbers that you rattled off in the 10-K.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: And so what is that program specifically? Where is that $10 million going and is it -- what sort of investing hurdles?
componenttext: And so what is that program specifically? Where is that $10 million going and is it -- what sort of investing hurdles?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 06, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, what it is, it's based upon revenue growth targets and it's been given to various employees throughout the company. If certain revenue targets are hit, they will earn restricted stock units. And the way that restricted stock units are working is, is
componenttext: Yes, what it is, it's based upon revenue growth targets and it's been given to various employees throughout the company. If certain revenue targets are hit, they will earn restricted stock units. And the way that restricted stock units are working is, is that the -- because we think we will hit those revenue targets now, we had to start accruing the expense even though, the measurement dates of whether we hit the target or not won't be determined until, obviously, 2011 is over. But to give you some more clarity on the expense, the expense is front-end loaded over -- they've used their options or restricted stock, excuse me, vest over a 5-year period, and the expense is front-end loaded. The expense in the first year, which is 2011, will be $9 million. In 2012, we're estimating that expense to go down to $4.9 million. 2013 will be $2.9 million. 2014 will be $1.6 million, and then 2015 will be $700,000. So you could see the expense is hugely front-end loaded. And again, that will obviously depend -- it's all obviously contingent that we hit a certain revenue target, which right now, we believe, we will hit that revenue target.

componenttext: And that $19 million net worth -- because I know sometimes the allocation on the P&L is different than the value of the program because you have forfeiture grants and you have all these other things that go into it. This is the third year of the plan. And for the last 2 years, we've not hit the revenue targets, and so there's been no RSU grants for the previous 2 years. So this is the third year. We're hoping to hit the targets. I can tell you all the people participating in the plan are highly focused on hitting the targets because, as John mentioned, there's $20 million of RSU grants on the line.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Beverly, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Public Storage Second Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Clem Teng, you may begin your conf
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Beverly, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Public Storage Second Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Clem Teng, you may begin your conference.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us for our second quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner, CEO; and John Reyes, CFO. We'll follow the usual format followed by a question-and-answer period. However, to allow for equal participation
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us for our second quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner, CEO; and John Reyes, CFO. We'll follow the usual format followed by a question-and-answer period. However, to allow for equal participation, we request that you ask only one question when your turn comes up, and then return to the queue for any follow-up question. 
Before we start, I want to remind you that all statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements. These forward-looking statements are subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those projected in these statements. These risks and other factors that could adversely affect our business and future results are described in today's earnings press release, as well as in our reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. All forward-looking statements speak only as of today, August 5, 2011, and we assume no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. A reconciliation to GAAP of the non-GAAP financial measures we are providing on this call is included in our earnings press release. You can find our press release, SEC reports and the audio webcast replay of this conference call on our website at www.publicstorage.com. I'll turn the call over to John Reyes.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Clem. As outlined in our press release, our second quarter core FFO per share was $1.43 compared to $1.27 last year, a 13% increase. Three items primarily drove this growth: first, our same-store net operating income increased by 6.2% or approx
componenttext:
Thank you, Clem. As outlined in our press release, our second quarter core FFO per share was $1.43 compared to $1.27 last year, a 13% increase. Three items primarily drove this growth: first, our same-store net operating income increased by 6.2% or approximately $15 million, representing $0.09 per share. Second, our investment in Shurgard Europe added $0.05 per share, primarily from the acquisition of an 80% interest in 2 joint ventures, along with the 13% higher euro-to-dollar currency exchange rate. Third, our nonsame-store properties added another $0.03 per share. These items were partially offset by higher G&A costs of about $0.02 per share. Our same-store net operating income benefited from higher revenues of 4%, along with flat operating expenses. Higher property taxes and property payroll expenses were offset by lower advertising, primarily due to lower television cost. 
Our G&A expense for the quarter was $2.5 million higher than last year. This is primarily due to an additional $3 million for an intensive plan that is based upon 2011 same-store revenue growth. We expect this plan will add $13 million to our 2011 G&A expense compared to 2010. We recently completed several capital transactions. During the second quarter, we issued $375 million of 6 1/2% preferred stock and we redeemed $518 million of 7 1/4% preferred stock. After the quarter, we issued $488 million of 6.35% preferred stock and called for redemption $425 million of 7 1/4% preferred stock. In the third quarter, there will be an associated EITF D-42 charge of approximately $13 million or $0.08 per share. 
As a result of these transactions, our quarterly preferred dividend will be about $1 million lower in the third quarter and $3 million lower in the fourth quarter as compared to the same periods last year. As previously announced, Shurgard Europe acquired in early March the remaining 8% interest in 2 joint ventures that owned 72 properties for $238 million. The transaction was initially funded as a dollar-denominated loan by Public Storage. In mid-June, our partner in Shurgard Europe funded its proportionate share of the investment. Although the loan bore interest at 7%, it effectively was a participating loan. Accordingly, from early March until mid-June, we received 100% of the income from the 80% interest in the 2 joint ventures. After mid-June, we began receiving our 49% share from the joint ventures. Our second quarter earnings were about $3 million higher than they otherwise would've been due to this brief period where we received 100% of the income. Also in the quarter, we agreed to purchase through mergers, the remaining partnership interest in 5 Public Storage-sponsored public partnership for $154 million. These partnerships owned 47 properties with 2.7 million square feet. The transaction, which is subject to conditions, is expected to close in the third quarter. With that, I will now turn you over to Ron.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. We had a good quarter benefiting from higher occupancy and better pricing. We added 31,000 net customers due to higher move-ins, offset in part by higher move-outs. We ended Q2 with record same-store occupancy of 93.1% and maintained a he
componenttext:
Thank you, John. We had a good quarter benefiting from higher occupancy and better pricing. We added 31,000 net customers due to higher move-ins, offset in part by higher move-outs. We ended Q2 with record same-store occupancy of 93.1% and maintained a healthy year-over-year spread of 1.5% despite a 50% reduction in media spend. Street rates were also higher, same-store revenue per available foot grew by 4% compared to 3% in Q1. At the end of July, occupancy and asking rents were also higher than the same period last year. All of our top U.S. markets achieved positive revenue growth in Q2. In addition, despite lower media spend, all but one had greater move-ins. Los Angeles, our largest market, grew revenues by 1.5% compared to 0.6% in Q1. Move-ins grew by 1.2% despite a 58% reduction in media spend. San Francisco, our second-largest market, increased revenues by 3.6%, up from 3% in Q1. Move-ins were up 2.1% despite a 56% decline in media spend. The Southeast markets, Florida and Georgia, grew by 4%, up from 3.4% in Q1. Move-ins were flat to last year while our media spend was down 42%. The Pacific Northwest markets, primarily Seattle and Portland, grew by 3.5% revenue, up from 2.4% in Q1. Move-ins were up by 3.8% while our media spend was flat. The Northeast market, Boston, New York, D.C. and Philadelphia, grew revenues by 5.9%, down from 6% in Q1. Move-ins also declined to 3.2%. Media spend was declined by 23%. Our top-performing market was Detroit at 6.3% revenue growth. 
Our third quarter media spend is expected to be about the same as last year. Moving to our European operations, our same stores had top line growth of 1%, resulting from higher realized rents and higher occupancy. We ended Q2 with positive occupancy spread of 0.4%, up from a negative 0.2% at the end of Q1. We expect modest revenue growth for the balance of the year. Operating expenses were 4% higher, primarily from higher advertising and property taxes, resulting in negative NOI growth of 1.5%. With respect to acquisitions, we acquired another 3 properties for $40 million with about 300,000 net rentable square feet. 
In summary, our trends remain solid. Occupancies are higher, asking rents are higher, our cost of preferred securities are lower, our leverage is lower. We feel pretty good about delivering double-digit growth, with debt and preferred at 16% capitalization and in excess of 4.5x fixed charge coverage. With that, operator, let's open it up for questions.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011

componenttext: Rent rate increases, most of it is from the increases to existing tenants, combined with higher occupancy. The new tenants that are coming in are coming in flattish to down compared to last year because our market rates are pretty flat.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: I like to know what are the renewals, what the percentages of renewals you're sending out right now for August and September? But also if you can tell us that in dollar terms, what are the average dollar amounts being sent out and maybe by market?
componenttext: I like to know what are the renewals, what the percentages of renewals you're sending out right now for August and September? But also if you can tell us that in dollar terms, what are the average dollar amounts being sent out and maybe by market?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, that's a pretty difficult question for conference call by market. Let me just tell you broadly what we're doing. Let me say what we did during the first half. The first half of the year, we sent out about 3.2% less renewals than we did last yea
componenttext: I'm sorry, that's a pretty difficult question for conference call by market. Let me just tell you broadly what we're doing. Let me say what we did during the first half. The first half of the year, we sent out about 3.2% less renewals than we did last year during the first half. The renewals that we did send out during the first half of this year averaged about 8.5% compared to last year, which was about 5.3%. During the second half of last year, we sent out what we're to send out this year versus last year. we're scheduled to send out about 25% more letters in the second half or increases, I should say, than we did last year. The projected increases this year will be about 9.1% versus 6.7% last year. The bulk of the increases that we will be sending out this year have already happened. They happened effective July 1, whereas last year, it was spread throughout from July into September. Not quite evenly, we sent out the bulk of them though on July 1 last year, but we did have a good chunk that went out in August, as well as September. This year, we will have no increases in August or September.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: So what does that translate into in terms of average dollars increase in terms of the increases?
componenttext: So what does that translate into in terms of average dollars increase in terms of the increases?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: You've obviously seen some success raising occupancy despite cutting back on media spend. There's been some talk among your peers about cutting back in concessions, one that did sell pretty meaningfully through the second quarter actually saw a negative r
componenttext: You've obviously seen some success raising occupancy despite cutting back on media spend. There's been some talk among your peers about cutting back in concessions, one that did sell pretty meaningfully through the second quarter actually saw a negative resulting impact on occupancy. So I'm wondering if you've cut back at all in concessions? And then just to sort of ask the rents question a little bit differently, is there any way that you could dissect? If you look at the 2.2% growth in your realized rent per occupied square foot, I know a lot of it was the inflation rate hikes but I'm just wondering if any of that had to do with maybe some burnoff of concessions that may have contributed to the upside in that number or higher asking rents, what were your asking rates year-over-year?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Christy, our concessions, we gave out about the same dollar amount of concessions as we did last year. So there was no benefit or detriment from concessions on that. We kept discounting throughout the period. Notwithstanding the fact that we had higher oc
componenttext: Christy, our concessions, we gave out about the same dollar amount of concessions as we did last year. So there was no benefit or detriment from concessions on that. We kept discounting throughout the period. Notwithstanding the fact that we had higher occupancy, we kept the concessions going because for 2 reasons: one, we knew we were cutting back on television and then the second reason is because we were sending out more aggressive rate increases to our tenants. We want to be able to backfill any vacancy that may have caused that move-out started accelerating. In terms of the rental rates charged to new, incoming tenants versus last year, it's about flat, Christy and our move-ins are up as Ron indicated, somewhat compared to last year. So we're not getting a big lift in our revenue growth from new move-ins.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011

componenttext: That was planned, Todd. No, we accelerated the timing in which we use it. We really don't do a whole lot during that timeframe traditionally and we felt this year rather than doing them, we decided to accelerate them and basically get all the letters or the increases out earlier this year.

componenttext: And then Ron, I was just wondering, a couple of other management teams this quarter made the statement that the discretionary renter is no longer around, that the renter base is comprised of mostly needs-based renters, unlike in front of the last recession a couple of years back. Do you agree with that as you think about your portfolio in the industry today?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't know that the customer has changed, and to be honest, I don't know how they know. If you look across our portfolio, I cited move-in volumes across various markets from Los Angeles to San Francisco to Florida to Seattle. Move-in volumes were up acr
componenttext: I don't know that the customer has changed, and to be honest, I don't know how they know. If you look across our portfolio, I cited move-in volumes across various markets from Los Angeles to San Francisco to Florida to Seattle. Move-in volumes were up across the platform despite lower media spend other than the Northeast. The Northeast has been strong for the past year, 1.5 years. But the rate of growth is slowing in the Northeast. Still great, absolute revenue growth, 5.9% but it's slowing. We're able to drop media spend and still have higher move-ins. So I would say that fundamentally, that would indicate to me the customer base has not changed really at all.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Spector with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Spector with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: If we can talk a little bit about the housing market and it seems that trends continue to weaken there, the customer you're seeing coming into your portfolio, are those customers that have been foreclosed on, forced out of their homes or those are folks t
componenttext: If we can talk a little bit about the housing market and it seems that trends continue to weaken there, the customer you're seeing coming into your portfolio, are those customers that have been foreclosed on, forced out of their homes or those are folks that have sold in the downturn and now are renting?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Jeff, over the last couple of years, we have seen more people come in to our space as a result of foreclosures, and probably less people come in to our space as a result of move-in because there's less move-in velocity in the economy. But as I just answer
componenttext: Jeff, over the last couple of years, we have seen more people come in to our space as a result of foreclosures, and probably less people come in to our space as a result of move-in because there's less move-in velocity in the economy. But as I just answered the other question, which I think Todd asked, if you look across the platform, we're seeing higher move-in volumes across the entire United States, even in Las Vegas. The only place where we're not seeing is really in the Northeast. So all indications from our perspective, and we're at record high occupancies, is that the customer base is essentially the same. And it's people moving from changes in life circumstances.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: So basically, if we continue to see home prices decline here, there's really nothing to read into it that you may start to see less demand in your portfolio for self storage?
componenttext: So basically, if we continue to see home prices decline here, there's really nothing to read into it that you may start to see less demand in your portfolio for self storage?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: If the last set of stats that I saw in home prices, I think Detroit was -- if it wasn't the worst, it was near the top 3 in terms of declines in home prices, and we had record revenues in Detroit this quarter at 6.3%. Detroit finished the quarter, I wante
componenttext: If the last set of stats that I saw in home prices, I think Detroit was -- if it wasn't the worst, it was near the top 3 in terms of declines in home prices, and we had record revenues in Detroit this quarter at 6.3%. Detroit finished the quarter, I wanted to say, about 96%, 96.5% occupancy.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Gotham from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Gotham from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Purely from a same-store NOI perspective, I think last quarter, Illinois was the weakest. It had a 2.4% decline and Texas was about a 7% increase. Has that trend changed and what are your expectations for the difference of the markets over the next 12 to
componenttext: Purely from a same-store NOI perspective, I think last quarter, Illinois was the weakest. It had a 2.4% decline and Texas was about a 7% increase. Has that trend changed and what are your expectations for the difference of the markets over the next 12 to 15 months?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: The Chicago market, on an NOI basis, is they're one of our weaker in terms of the big markets. Part of the problem is not on the revenue side. It's on the expense side due to some property taxes, as well as one of the big things with snow removal costs th
componenttext: The Chicago market, on an NOI basis, is they're one of our weaker in terms of the big markets. Part of the problem is not on the revenue side. It's on the expense side due to some property taxes, as well as one of the big things with snow removal costs this year versus last year. That will obviously go away and it should get back to positive trends going into the third and fourth quarters. Texas has been strong and it still remains very strong, particularly Dallas. Dallas, Austin, San Antonio have been very good. Houston's probably the most weakest of the Texas market but nonetheless, it's positive trending.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me try to give you a little bit more color on that as well to what John said. If you kind of look at our top 5 or 6 markets in terms of revenue growth quarter-over-quarter, it's Detroit at 6.3%, Dallas at 6.2% and New York at 5.9%. Northern Virginia,
componenttext: Let me try to give you a little bit more color on that as well to what John said. If you kind of look at our top 5 or 6 markets in terms of revenue growth quarter-over-quarter, it's Detroit at 6.3%, Dallas at 6.2% and New York at 5.9%. Northern Virginia, D.C. at 5.7%, Philly at 5.4% and Minneapolis at 5.3%. At the bottom here is L.A. at 1.5% and Sacramento at 2.4% and San Francisco's in there at 3.6%. But if you look at the sequential rate of change in the revenue growth, at the top of the group, you're going to put in Portland at 2.1%, Orlando at 1.8%, Minneapolis at 1.6%, Tampa at 1.4% and then there's Los Angeles at 0.9% and San Francisco at 0.6%. Down there at the bottom, the markets that are actually slowing down a little bit are D.C. down 0.6%, Philly down 1.3% and New York down 1.1%. So it's kind of touches on this growth that the growth is decelerating in the Northeast and picking up on the coast and the Southeast.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Michael Knott with Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Michael Knott with Green Street Advisors.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ron, just curious to your opinion if we do head into a recession here, do you think your currently strong trends will weaken somewhat or do you think it'll be a nonevent as One of your peers kind of suggest this morning?
componenttext: Ron, just curious to your opinion if we do head into a recession here, do you think your currently strong trends will weaken somewhat or do you think it'll be a nonevent as One of your peers kind of suggest this morning?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well Michael, peers, I'm not sure we have any peers. But so far, we're record high occupancies and we're seeing growth across the platform. So if there's a deterioration in the business, we're not seeing it right now.
componenttext: Well Michael, peers, I'm not sure we have any peers. But so far, we're record high occupancies and we're seeing growth across the platform. So if there's a deterioration in the business, we're not seeing it right now.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess I'm just curious as to your thoughts on you think plus storage is recession resistant or not? What would your sort of takeaway be from the last cycle as it might apply to if we do have a very slight dip in economic activity here?
componenttext: I guess I'm just curious as to your thoughts on you think plus storage is recession resistant or not? What would your sort of takeaway be from the last cycle as it might apply to if we do have a very slight dip in economic activity here?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think those words are very appropriate, recession resistant. In particular, in our portfolio, the West Coast has lagged the rest of the portfolio in terms of growth. So we're kind of sitting here looking at okay, sometime next year West Coast markets wi
componenttext: I think those words are very appropriate, recession resistant. In particular, in our portfolio, the West Coast has lagged the rest of the portfolio in terms of growth. So we're kind of sitting here looking at okay, sometime next year West Coast markets will be picking up and leading in terms of growth. So if I kind of look at our portfolio is we've got some momentum in the portfolio and some growth still to go because of our concentration here in the West Coast. But I think your term of recession resistant is very appropriate.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just from a capital allocation standpoint, how do you think about long-term or even sort of intermediate term rental growth in secondary markets as compared to coastal markets would just that earlier this season, that may be the secondary type ma
componenttext: And then just from a capital allocation standpoint, how do you think about long-term or even sort of intermediate term rental growth in secondary markets as compared to coastal markets would just that earlier this season, that may be the secondary type markets really haven't trailed, coastal high barrier peers, all that much over historical period and maybe the underwriting that causes cap rates spreads to be 150 basis points or so is too wide and not right. What's your view on secondary markets versus coastal markets from a capital allocation standpoint?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll be rather blunt, I will take Manhattan or Northern Virginia or Los Angeles over Cleveland or Cincinnati, Ohio any day.
componenttext: Well, I'll be rather blunt, I will take Manhattan or Northern Virginia or Los Angeles over Cleveland or Cincinnati, Ohio any day.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Todd Stender with Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Todd Stender with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: My question had to do with the completed conversion of the facility in L.A. Do you have any other opportunities for that and what kind of markets would you look at?
componenttext: My question had to do with the completed conversion of the facility in L.A. Do you have any other opportunities for that and what kind of markets would you look at?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: That was an existing opportunity of a property that we owned here in Los Angeles and we don't have many more of those opportunities in our portfolio. There might be one or two coming down the pipe in the next couple of years, but nothing further. It's a g
componenttext: That was an existing opportunity of a property that we owned here in Los Angeles and we don't have many more of those opportunities in our portfolio. There might be one or two coming down the pipe in the next couple of years, but nothing further. It's a great site, along with 2 major freeways in an area that we didn't have products. So it will fit well inside our portfolio.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: What market is that in and do you know any of the occupancies within that market?
componenttext: What market is that in and do you know any of the occupancies within that market?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: It was in the Torrance market, along the 405 freeway, just north of the 410.
componenttext: It was in the Torrance market, along the 405 freeway, just north of the 410.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: And some markets who are pretty fully occupied 95% plus.
componenttext: And some markets who are pretty fully occupied 95% plus.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of Paula Poskon with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of Paula Poskon with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Given that operating trends that you're seeing, particularly around occupancy, do you expect the seasonal decline in occupancy heading towards the winter to be somewhat more muted in the coming months? And if so, by how much?
componenttext: Given that operating trends that you're seeing, particularly around occupancy, do you expect the seasonal decline in occupancy heading towards the winter to be somewhat more muted in the coming months? And if so, by how much?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: I wish it would be muted. I don't expect it to be muted because there's nothing that I've seen in the trends that would suggest that. So I think it's going to be very comparable to us, the seasonality has been, at least over the past couple of years.
componenttext: I wish it would be muted. I don't expect it to be muted because there's nothing that I've seen in the trends that would suggest that. So I think it's going to be very comparable to us, the seasonality has been, at least over the past couple of years.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Omotayo Okusanya from Jefferies & Co.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Omotayo Okusanya from Jefferies & Co.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to get a sense of what you are seeing in regards to operating trends, both in July and the early part of August?
componenttext: Just wanted to get a sense of what you are seeing in regards to operating trends, both in July and the early part of August?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think I gave you that we were higher occupancy at the end of July. And we say about 92.9% versus 91.6% and our asking rates were higher at the end of July than they were last year. In terms of August, that will kind of be in our Q3 results.
componenttext: I think I gave you that we were higher occupancy at the end of July. And we say about 92.9% versus 91.6% and our asking rates were higher at the end of July than they were last year. In terms of August, that will kind of be in our Q3 results.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then second question, with regards to opportunities to do things internationally. I know some of the few assets are in Canada and there's always been talk about you possibly doing additional in the U.K.
componenttext: And then second question, with regards to opportunities to do things internationally. I know some of the few assets are in Canada and there's always been talk about you possibly doing additional in the U.K.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry. I'm not sure what your question is.
componenttext: I'm sorry. I'm not sure what your question is.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: My question is your thoughts on further international expansion just given some of the huge assets are in Canada and in the past, there's always been talk about you doing something in regards to the public utilities?
componenttext: My question is your thoughts on further international expansion just given some of the huge assets are in Canada and in the past, there's always been talk about you doing something in regards to the public utilities?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Oh, we don't comment on mergers or acquisition, public company acquisitions on a conference call. And the Shurgard Europe, we own 49% of it, our partner, New York Common Retirement Fund owns 51% of it. And so expansion plans over there, it's really a join
componenttext: Oh, we don't comment on mergers or acquisition, public company acquisitions on a conference call. And the Shurgard Europe, we own 49% of it, our partner, New York Common Retirement Fund owns 51% of it. And so expansion plans over there, it's really a joint decision. We have in some sense, had a meaningful expansion there by taking out our joint venture partner, which was about $240 million earlier in the year. So you can look at that in once sense as expansion in Europe and both Public Storage and New York Common contributed to the funding of that acquisition. With respect to Canada, that is really -- the Hughes family owns that and that's really their decision in terms of what they want to do with it.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just the last question, when you kind of look at the market conditions right now, I know what circumstances would you feel more comfortable to try to push your street rates?
componenttext: Just the last question, when you kind of look at the market conditions right now, I know what circumstances would you feel more comfortable to try to push your street rates?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Right now, we're not going to be pushing our street rates. We're going to be competitive. We believe right now, our rates are higher than where the market is right now. So there's no sense in us being aggressive, pushing rates right now. And I can't tell
componenttext: Right now, we're not going to be pushing our street rates. We're going to be competitive. We believe right now, our rates are higher than where the market is right now. So there's no sense in us being aggressive, pushing rates right now. And I can't tell you why the market's not raising their rates. But we feel we don't need to be doing that right now. As we've mentioned before, growth in our revenues is going to come from increasing the renewals to our existing tenant base and we're still living by that strategy and we continue that for the remainder of the year.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: One other thing you should know, or you should put in mind is starting July and certainly August, the balance of the year is going to be a net kind of it is a net outflow. So occupancy declines after July each month. So in terms of being aggressive in our
componenttext: One other thing you should know, or you should put in mind is starting July and certainly August, the balance of the year is going to be a net kind of it is a net outflow. So occupancy declines after July each month. So in terms of being aggressive in our rental rates, we won't because we want to be able to backfill that space from customers moving out on a seasonal basis.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Mueller with J.P. Morgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Mueller with J.P. Morgan.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: First Ron, can you just repeat what you are saying about the July occupancy levels, the July end occupancy levels, and then the question is if you could switch over the way you do your pricing recently to conform more to how you do in the U.S., I'm just w
componenttext: First Ron, can you just repeat what you are saying about the July occupancy levels, the July end occupancy levels, and then the question is if you could switch over the way you do your pricing recently to conform more to how you do in the U.S., I'm just wondering what you can tell us about how that's progressing.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, the July occupancies I quoted were 92.9% versus 91.6%. And with respect to Europe and the pricing, that's just gotten underway. So it's too early to say kind of what will be happening or the impact of that in terms of our having greater participation
componenttext: Yes, the July occupancies I quoted were 92.9% versus 91.6%. And with respect to Europe and the pricing, that's just gotten underway. So it's too early to say kind of what will be happening or the impact of that in terms of our having greater participation in pricing in Europe versus not. So it's too early to tell.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Smedes Rose of KBW.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Smedes Rose of KBW.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask you on the partnerships you're buying out, are there more of those that you could buy out over time? And then just in terms of the effect on your income statement, is that basically eliminates most of that minority interest or other n
componenttext: I just wanted to ask you on the partnerships you're buying out, are there more of those that you could buy out over time? And then just in terms of the effect on your income statement, is that basically eliminates most of that minority interest or other noncontrolling interest and subsidiaries as fees are consolidated?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: On the second question, the accounting, you're correct. It's minority interest. On the first question, how much, this represents about 1/2 of all of our minority interest, excluding Shurgard Europe.
componenttext: On the second question, the accounting, you're correct. It's minority interest. On the first question, how much, this represents about 1/2 of all of our minority interest, excluding Shurgard Europe.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: I mean was there a reason for the timing of why buying these out now or I just wanted more color I guess, because these are old established partnerships or limited partnerships.
componenttext: I mean was there a reason for the timing of why buying these out now or I just wanted more color I guess, because these are old established partnerships or limited partnerships.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, they're about 30-plus years old. It seems there are a variety of things that went into the decision. Again, there's a public document that you could kind of go through and read all about that.
componenttext: Yes, they're about 30-plus years old. It seems there are a variety of things that went into the decision. Again, there's a public document that you could kind of go through and read all about that.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's 300 pages. I'll crawl through it.
componenttext: It's 300 pages. I'll crawl through it.

componenttext: Just a quick follow-up. On your comment about decrease in street rates, I was wondering if you keep that or provide perspective on a year-over-year basis, because we know that's from a year-over-year perspective how would that look like going forward?

componenttext: Ki, the end of July, the street rates were higher than last year. Is that your question?

componenttext: Yes, along that, right.

componenttext: But still higher year-over-year?

componenttext: I don't know what they're going to be in August, September, October but at the end of July, they were higher.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Are you simply following the output from your pricing systems or are you keeping it little more subjective given kind of the negative macro you're seeing?
componenttext: Are you simply following the output from your pricing systems or are you keeping it little more subjective given kind of the negative macro you're seeing?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry. Your question, can you please repeat that?
componenttext: I'm sorry. Your question, can you please repeat that?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: So you guys have pretty sophisticated pricing systems that look at occupancy levels and competing occupancy levels. Are you following the output from your pricing systems pretty closely or are you making some subjective pricing changes?
componenttext: So you guys have pretty sophisticated pricing systems that look at occupancy levels and competing occupancy levels. Are you following the output from your pricing systems pretty closely or are you making some subjective pricing changes?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: We're making a lot of subjective pricing changes.
componenttext: We're making a lot of subjective pricing changes.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: And last part, Shurgard Europe seems to have operations slowed down a little bit this quarter. And on the expense side, so I guess if you could provide a little more commentary on how -- if the level expenses are here to stay, given maybe just higher leve
componenttext: And last part, Shurgard Europe seems to have operations slowed down a little bit this quarter. And on the expense side, so I guess if you could provide a little more commentary on how -- if the level expenses are here to stay, given maybe just higher level of taxes going forward, if you can provide us a little more color on that?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ki. Europe's P&L on the expense side, I think you hit on the 2 key items. Property taxes, there was a property tax refund last year during Q2. There wasn't a corresponding one this year. So that's why the key tax is up. And advertising was a little
componenttext: Sure, Ki. Europe's P&L on the expense side, I think you hit on the 2 key items. Property taxes, there was a property tax refund last year during Q2. There wasn't a corresponding one this year. So that's why the key tax is up. And advertising was a little more front-end loaded into the year, the front part of the year. And last year, I think advertising year-to-date is up 13%. So I'd expect some moderation in that growth for the balance of the year. If you kind of unbundle Europe and look at revenue growth by market, there's one particular market that has about 15%, 18% of the portfolio. That's Holland. And Holland's revenue in Q2 was down 5.4%. That contrasts with markets like Sweden up 3.8%, France up 2%. The U.K. was up by 1.4% quarter-to-quarter, Belgium was up 3.5%. So overall, we're doing pretty darn good in Europe but we've got, so to speak, one problem market and that's Holland.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Salinsky with RBC Capital Markets.

componenttext: Well sequentially, occupancies in Europe moved from 86.4% in June to 86.5% in July. Street rates are about comparable to last year. So we haven't seen any big degradation in demand here in Europe for the month of July.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well Michael, historically and best as I can tell, perspectively, we're not really sellers of assets because we're trying to continually build upon our platform. So we're looking for assets that are additive and not only create value in their own right bu
componenttext: Well Michael, historically and best as I can tell, perspectively, we're not really sellers of assets because we're trying to continually build upon our platform. So we're looking for assets that are additive and not only create value in their own right but additive the platform. So we're generally not sellers of assets. I can't on a conference call, go through it portfolio by portfolio but I'm relatively familiar with a lot of which transaction. Our team here sees pretty much every thing that goes down in the market, and I don't know what to add to what I already said in terms of there's a gap in price between what we think is worth and what someone else is thinking it's worth. And there's a gap in terms of what we perceive to be quality assets versus what other people perceive to be quality assets. I don't know what else to add to that.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011

componenttext: I guess I'm trying to get a perspective of really what that gap is, right? Because if there's a certain amount of -- you are in a size, and a portfolio size where the portfolio drives significant value to the whole, to each individual piece, right? Because you don't want to take anything out of the portfolio even if you think it's of similar quality to what's transacted and you don't want to take it out even though you could get it an attractive price because it's more valuable to be inside the whole portfolio than outside, then the gap's got to be so large to not take in one of these portfolios into the empire to drive growth even further and enlarge the pipeline, right?

componenttext: Ron, I think I remember correctly it's either the last conference or the conference call before, you referenced to the management issues in the Netherlands, and I think you just threw out some stats, which suggest things aren't getting much better. Is that issue resolved now?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, David. We put in a new, what we call a market manager, which is kind of the equivalent of a regional manager here in the U.S. He's been in place about a year. We've upgraded a number of the district manager positions over the last year as well. So Ho
componenttext: Yes, David. We put in a new, what we call a market manager, which is kind of the equivalent of a regional manager here in the U.S. He's been in place about a year. We've upgraded a number of the district manager positions over the last year as well. So Holland is on its way to recovery. I got one more stat here I can share with you. In terms of -- I touched earlier with someone on sequential revenue growth, while Holland was down 5.4% quarter-on-a-quarter, on a sequential basis, it's actually improved 0.1%. So we're cautiously optimistic on Holland. And we've got some good people in place and we just need to give them some time. Good assets and good people in place. So I think next year, Holland will be a positive story to talk about.

componenttext: It may but keep in mind in Europe, self storage market across Western Europe is only about 1,500 facilities, and I would say that the percentage of those that are purpose built that we would be truly interested in is probably 100 to 200 across Europe. So there may be some opportunities there. I think last year, we did buy 2 foreclosed assets, one in Holland and one in the U.K. But I will not see that as nearly as a robust pipeline as we have here in the U.S.

componenttextpreview: Ron, just a follow-up on the fund question from a minute ago. Up until maybe the last couple of weeks, maybe your stock had traded as high as maybe a 50% in AV premium, something like that. Currently, do you view that as kind of a mandate to go out and bu
componenttext: Ron, just a follow-up on the fund question from a minute ago. Up until maybe the last couple of weeks, maybe your stock had traded as high as maybe a 50% in AV premium, something like that. Currently, do you view that as kind of a mandate to go out and buy? It seems like that would suggest that by not going out and paying market for deals that may be you're leaving money on the table? How do you think about that cost of capital advantage that you have versus your decision to say that some of these other deals, lower-priced are not appropriate for you?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Michael, I guess I would answer that a couple of ways. One, I think one of the reasons we do have the premium in our stock price is because we consider ourselves reasonably disciplined. I don't want to say that we don't make mistakes but we try to b
componenttext: Well, Michael, I guess I would answer that a couple of ways. One, I think one of the reasons we do have the premium in our stock price is because we consider ourselves reasonably disciplined. I don't want to say that we don't make mistakes but we try to be pretty disciplined with respect to buying. And I think that is in part, reflected in the multiple. Two, in terms of buying stuff, I'd said this often. It's easy to buy stuff, you just show up with the biggest check. So we could buy as much real estate as we want and we just show up with the biggest check. And over time, I think our premium to NAV would dissipate. Given the market, given the deterioration of the CMBS market, given where the banks are moving with respect to asset disposition and the upcoming debt maturities, I am quite confident we will have plenty of opportunities to deploy capital here in the next year or 2. So from my perspective, I'm not worried about that will. We will remain disciplined and I think that is, in part, why our stock, is what you said, 50% NAV premium.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Beverly, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Public Storage Second Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Clem Teng, you may begin your conf
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Beverly, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Public Storage Second Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Clem Teng, you may begin your conference.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us for our second quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner, CEO; and John Reyes, CFO. We'll follow the usual format followed by a question-and-answer period. However, to allow for equal participation
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us for our second quarter earnings call. Here with me today are Ron Havner, CEO; and John Reyes, CFO. We'll follow the usual format followed by a question-and-answer period. However, to allow for equal participation, we request that you ask only one question when your turn comes up, and then return to the queue for any follow-up questions.
Before we start, I want to remind you that all statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements. These forward-looking statements are subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that can cause actual results to differ materially from those projected in these statements. These risks and other factors that could adversely affect our business and future results are described in today's earnings press release, as well as in our reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. All forward-looking statements speak only as of today, August 5, 2011, and we assume no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. A reconciliation to GAAP of the non-GAAP financial measures we are providing on this call is included in our earnings press release. You can find our press release, SEC reports and the audio webcast replay of this conference call on our website at www.publicstorage.com. I'll turn the call over to John Reyes.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Clem. As outlined in our press release, our second quarter core FFO per share was $1.43 compared to $1.27 last year, a 13% increase. Three items primarily drove this growth. First, our same-store net operating income increased by 6.2% or approx
componenttext:
Thank you, Clem. As outlined in our press release, our second quarter core FFO per share was $1.43 compared to $1.27 last year, a 13% increase. Three items primarily drove this growth. First, our same-store net operating income increased by 6.2% or approximately $15 million, representing $0.09 per share. Second, our investment in Shurgard Europe added $0.05 per share, primarily from the acquisition of an 80% interest in 2 joint ventures, along with the 13% higher euro-to-dollar currency exchange rate. Third, our nonsame-store properties added another $0.03 per share. These items were partially offset by higher G&A costs of about $0.02 per share. Our same-store net operating income benefited from higher revenues of 4%, along with flat operating expenses. Higher property taxes and property payroll expenses were offset by lower advertising, primarily due to lower television cost.
Our G&A expense for the quarter was $2.5 million higher than last year. This is primarily due to an additional $3 million for an intensive plan that is based upon 2011 same-store revenue growth. We expect this plan will add $13 million to our 2011 G&A expense compared to 2010. We recently completed several capital transactions. During the second quarter, we issued $375 million of 6.5% preferred stock, and we redeemed $518 million of 7.25% preferred stock. After the quarter, we issued $488 million of 6.35% preferred stock and called for redemption $425 million of 7.25% preferred stock. In the third quarter, there will be an associated EITF D-42 charge of approximately $13 million or $0.08 per share.
As a result of these transactions, our quarterly preferred dividend will be about $1 million lower in the third quarter and $3 million lower in the fourth quarter as compared to the same periods last year. As previously announced, Shurgard Europe acquired in early March the remaining 8% interest in 2 joint ventures that owned 72 properties for $238 million. The transaction was initially funded as a dollar-denominated loan by Public Storage. In mid-June, our partner in Shurgard Europe funded its proportionate share of the investment. Although the loan bore interest at 7%, it effectively was a participating loan. Accordingly, from early March until mid-June, we received 100% of the income from the 80% interest in the 2 joint ventures. After mid-June, we began receiving our 49% share from the joint ventures. Our second quarter earnings were about $3 million higher than they otherwise would have been due to this brief period where we received 100% of the income. Also in the quarter, we agreed to purchase through mergers, the remaining partnership interest in 5 Public Storage-sponsored partnerships for $154 million. These partnerships owned 47 properties with 2.7 million square feet. The transaction, which is subject to conditions, is expected to close in the third quarter. With that, I will now turn you over to Ron.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. We had a good quarter benefiting from higher occupancy and better pricing. We added 31,000 net customers due to higher move-ins, offset in part by higher move-outs. We ended Q2 with record same-store occupancy of 93.1% and maintained a he
componenttext:
Thank you, John. We had a good quarter benefiting from higher occupancy and better pricing. We added 31,000 net customers due to higher move-ins, offset in part by higher move-outs. We ended Q2 with record same-store occupancy of 93.1% and maintained a healthy year-over-year spread of 1.5% despite a 50% reduction in media spend. Street rates were also higher. Same-store revenue per available foot grew by 4% compared to 3% in Q1. At the end of July, occupancy and asking rents were also higher than the same period last year. All of our top U.S. markets achieved positive revenue growth in Q2. In addition, despite lower media spend, all but one had greater move-ins. Los Angeles, our largest market, grew revenues by 1.5% compared to 0.6% in Q1. Move-ins grew by 1.2% despite a 58% reduction in media spend. San Francisco, our second-largest market, increased revenues by 3.6%, up from 3% in Q1. Move-ins were up 2.1% despite a 56% decline in media spend. The Southeast markets, Florida and Georgia, grew by 4%, up from 3.4% in Q1. Move-ins were flat to last year while our media spend was down 42%. The Pacific Northwest markets, primarily Seattle and Portland, grew by 3.5% revenue, up from 2.4% in Q1. Move-ins were up by 3.8% while our media spend was flat. The Northeast market, Boston, New York, D.C. and Philadelphia, grew revenues by 5.9%, down from 6% in Q1. Move-ins also declined by 3.2%. Media spend was declined by 23%. Our top-performing market was Detroit at 6.3% revenue growth.
Our third quarter media spend is expected to be about the same as last year. Moving to our European operations, our same stores had top line growth of 1%, resulting from higher realized rents and higher occupancy. We ended Q2 with positive occupancy spread of 0.4%, up from a negative 0.2% at the end of Q1. We expect modest revenue growth for the balance of the year. Operating expenses were 4% higher, primarily from higher advertising and property taxes, resulting in negative NOI growth of 1.5%. With respect to acquisitions, we acquired another 3 properties for $40 million with about 300,000 net rentable square feet.
In summary, our trends remain solid. Occupancies are higher. Asking rents are higher. Our cost of preferred securities are lower. Our leverage is lower. We feel pretty good about delivering double-digit growth with debt and preferred at 16% of capitalization and in excess of 4.5x fixed charge coverage. With that, operator, let's open it up for questions.

componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, that's a pretty difficult question for conference call by market. Let me just tell you broadly what we're doing. Let me tell you what we did during the first half. The first half of the year, we sent out about 3.2% less renewal than we did last
componenttext: I'm sorry, that's a pretty difficult question for conference call by market. Let me just tell you broadly what we're doing. Let me tell you what we did during the first half. The first half of the year, we sent out about 3.2% less renewal than we did last year during the first half. The renewals that we did send out during the first half of this year averaged about 8.5% compared to last year, which was about 5.3%. During the second half of last year, we sent out what we're scheduling to send out this year versus last year. We're scheduled to send out about 25% more letters in the second half or increases, I should say, than we did last year. The projected increases this year will be about 9.1% versus 6.7% last year. The bulk of the increases that we will be sending out this year have already happened. They happened effective July 1. Whereas last year, it was spread throughout from July into September. Not quite evenly, we sent out the bulk of them though on July 1 last year, but we did have a good chunk that went out in August, as well as September. This year, we will have no increases in August or September.

componenttext: Sure. So what does that translate into in terms of average dollars increase in terms of the increases?
